issues.title: [Edge] The “Must be a valid email” error message is displayed briefly when a breach search is performed
issues.body:
**[Note]:**
- This issue is reproducible on:
https://monitor.firefox.com/
https://stage.firefoxmonitor.nonprod.cloudops.mozgcp.net/
https://monitor-v2.herokuapp.com/

**[Affected Versions]:**
- Microsoft Edge version 44.18362.449.0

**[Affected Platforms]:**
- Windows 10 (x64)

**[Prerequisites]:**
- You are on the [Firefox Monitor](https://monitor.firefox.com/) mainpage.

**[Steps to reproduce]:**
1. Enter a valid email in the email text field.
2. Click the "Check for Breaches" button and observe the email field.

**[Expected results]:**
- The email field is displayed in the default state until the breach scan page loads.

**[Actual results]:**
- The email field is highlighted with a red outline and the “Must be a valid email address” message is displayed in the time between clicking on the button and the breach scan page loading.

**[Additional Notes]:**
- This issue also affects all the branches of the Opt-in/Opt-out Experiment (#1587) when the checkbox is unchecked or not displayed.
- This issue is not reproducible on Edge Beta (v. 81.0.416.41) on Windows 10 (x64) or Edge for Android (v. 45.02.4.426) on Android 9.
- This issue is not reproducible on Firefox Release 74.0 (Build ID 20200309095159), Chrome (v. 80.0.3987.149) on Windows 10 (x64) or Firefox Preview (v. 4.1.0 Build #20771637) on Android 9.
- Attached is a recording of the issue.
![old edge specific](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53752296/78023904-28fdd580-7360-11ea-9ca2-c2dcb964aac0.gif)

issues.title: Changing Firefox account email cleared my Firefox Monitor data
issues.body: I updated my email address for my Firefox account and when I logged into Firefox Monitor using updated credentials, all my previous data was gone.

issues.title: Add icon/code for Firefox monitor to work with Safari ‘add to home screen’ function
issues.body:
Firefox Monitor is missing an icon that allows iOS users to add to home screen to appear like a native app. (Currently the icon just lookS like a string of text.)

FireFox Send is setup correctly, and it would be great to have FireFox monitor app on my iOS too because I love the way all the apps are presented in a dashboard.

Ideally I would always prefer to work in Firefox, but until links are added in Firefox iOS to Send and Monitor (similar to how desktop is now) Having these links/apps close at hand is a great work around until that time.

Proposed Process:

- Update line of code and icon on Firefox Monitor website to allow for proper use of Safari ‘Add to home screen’ function.

issues.title: On Google Chrome keyboard navigation is not  visible
issues.body:
**Affected versions**
- Google Chrome Version 80.0.3987.149 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
**Affected platforms**
- Windows 10 and 7 x64
- Mac OS X 10.14
- Ubuntu 18.04 

**Steps to reproduce**

issues.title: Error Cannot read property 'includes' of undefined
issues.body:
Filed by @cpeterso in Slack:

> _"I logged into monitor.firefox.com today and https://monitor.firefox.com/user/dashboard just shows me an error: `Error Cannot read property 'includes' of undefined`."_

Looking at Sentry, it's possibly coming from here:

https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/0d91dacc40e044e95c39bf19cdb21e0ca1974a6e/template-helpers/dashboard.js#L7-L9

But I'll need to dig through more sentry reports to see if a similar error is coming from anywhere else. Conversely, I can try scanning the source for any usage of `.includes()`.

issues.title: Consider adding alternate "Email Successfully Verified!" messaging for signed in users.
issues.body: Right now this is what users see when they verify a secondary email, even if they're signed in. #1495 hides the `To see and manage all emails you've signed up for breach monitoring, sign in` message from signed in users but it might be nice to replace this with some alternate "next step"/"go to your dashboard" messaging.

issues.title: Add good-first-bug GitHub label to qualifying issues
issues.body:
Re: https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+sort%3Aupdated-desc+label%3Agood-first-issue

It might be nice to tag a few appropriate issues with "good-first-bug" labels so we can direct contributors to some good, quality issues.

issues.title: Redesign "Security Tips" to a scalable format
issues.body:
There is promising content generated on Moz.org that could co-existing on Monitor's Security Tips page to make it easier for our Monitor users to learn more about or educate themselves around privacy without anyone having to reinvent the wheel. 

We could leverage a platform like WordPress or change the design to make it easier for us to carry over existing Mozilla-created content by embedding or sharing articles/blog posts that make sense. Also understanding what kind of content does well on Monitor can be supporting data points to help guide strategy.

issues.title: Increase code coverage
issues.body:
Looking at the coveralls results in recent PRs, it looks like our code coverage is roughly 46%. Not sure how difficult it would be to backfill some tests and get the code coverage numbers up around 75-90%, or if that's a full Q1 worth of work.

> **RUN DETAILS**
> 213 of 524 branches covered (40.65%)
> Branch coverage included in aggregate %.
> 0 of 4 new or added lines in 1 file covered. (0.0%)
> 783 of 1637 relevant lines covered (47.83%)
> 3.7 hits per line

But it'd be nice if we could increase the coverage numbers so we have more confidence in adding new code or refactoring existing code while adding new features/functionality.

issues.title: Update empty signup_language values with FxA profile locale value during FxA sign-ins
issues.body:
I think the TL;DR version is that early in Monitor's lifecycle, we weren't capturing user's locales. Now we're sending them emails in English, even though their locale is 99.5% translated (ie: es-MX and es-ES). User's also have no way of seeing/updating their preferred locales, so once we have it (or not) you're in that bucket for life (or stuck with fallback en-US).

It would be nice to be able to retroactively determine missing user locales, either via FxA or just the next time a logged in user visits the site.

Step 1 would be to run a DB query and determine how many people were super early Monitor adopters and signed up but we weren't capturing locales yet.

---

Via [Slack](https://mozilla.slack.com/archives/C93K0MBM5/p1574433398281900)

Luke Crouch 8:07 AM
@pdehaan oh, that’s a good idea. we don’t [backfill locales] right now, but we could try to use their fxa profile data locale …
@flodolo - is it pretty safe to assume that FxA’s locale value would be the “right” locale to use for Monitor too?

Francesco Lodolo 8:08 AM
Sorry, I have zero info on FxA. It might be

Luke Crouch 8:10 AM
@pdehaan can you file an issue for that? To update empty signup_language values with FxA profile locale value during FxA sign-ins.

issues.title: Clean up usage of `req.app.locals` to replace with `AppConstants`
issues.body:
_Originally posted by @groovecoder in https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/pull/1359_

> Can you file a follow-up issue to clean up our usage of `req.app.locals` to replace with `AppConstants` wherever we can?

Re: @pdehaan's brilliant https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/pull/1359#discussion_r346444248,

Interesting change... Here's a list of all the other unique instances where we use a `req.app.locals.<something>`:

```sh
git grep -Eho "req\.app\.locals\.\w*" | sort | uniq

req.app.locals.AVAILABLE_LANGUAGES
req.app.locals.FLUENT_BUNDLES
req.app.locals.SERVER_URL
req.app.locals.breaches
req.app.locals.mostRecentBreachDateTime
```

Looks like we have another `req.app.locals.SERVER_URL` instance in:

```
scan-results.js:48: req.app.locals.SERVER_URL
```

issues.title: Nudge users with pre-historic browsers to download Firefox.
issues.body: Let's detect ancient, unsupported browsers and alert the users using them that there is a much safer, much newer, much faster, extremely free browser named Firefox that is immediately available for download.

issues.title: Bonus browser redirect when navigating to HIBP (www.)
issues.body:
Per #1371, I noticed I was getting a 403 when scraping `https://www.haveibeenpwned.com` (and it redirects to lose the `www.` subdomain) when I visit directly.

```
[403] https://www.haveibeenpwned.com/
```

Not sure if it's worth it to "fix" the URL in our HBS views and save a browser redirect.

```
git grep -Eno "https://.*\.haveibeenpwned\.com"

.env-dist:49:https://stage.haveibeenpwned.com
.env-dist:53:https://api.haveibeenpwned.com
views/partials/email_partials/email_disclaimers.hbs:10:https://www.haveibeenpwned.com
views/partials/hibp-attribution.hbs:2:https://www.haveibeenpwned.com
```

issues.title: Link checker
issues.body:
Not sure if we want to use this for anything, but it's pretty interesting, and may be useful in some sort of pre-prod deploy checklist.

```sh
npx linkinator https://monitor.firefox.com -r --silent --no-color

[404] https://monitor.firefox.com/img/logos/ToonDoo.png
[403] https://www.haveibeenpwned.com/


https://monitor.firefox.com
  [404] https://monitor.firefox.com/img/logos/ToonDoo.png
https://monitor.firefox.com/breaches
  [403] https://www.haveibeenpwned.com/
ERROR: Detected 2 broken links. Scanned 22 links in 2.18 seconds.
```

Actually, this seems to have changed very recently. Looks like we did a production push and just added that missing ToonDoo.png logo.

As for the HIBP link which is 403ing, we can either remove the "www." subdomain from the link, or just add a config to ignore that domain/error/403:

```sh
npx linkinator https://monitor.firefox.com -r --silent --skip www.haveibeenpwned.com --no-color
```

issues.title: Update deps (Nov 2019 edition)
issues.body:
Looks like CI is failing due to an old **handlebars** vuln.

```
> blurts-server@0.0.1 lint:audit /home/travis/build/mozilla/blurts-server
> npm-audit-ci-wrapper -t 'high'
There are vulnerable dependencies which exceed the selected threshold and scope:
                        handlebars(4.3.0               ): https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1316              (high >= high)
```

Per https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1316,

> Remediation: Upgrade to version 4.5.2 or later

Currently we're using 4.3.0 via **express-handlebars** and **jest**.

issues.title: Webpage link 404s
issues.body:
This is completely random, and I believe a known issue, but I can't remember if we have a formal bug for it or not.

I randomly chose the following [Mastercard breach](https://monitor.firefox.com/breach-details/MastercardPricelessSpecials) to verify logos and clicked on the website URL, `www.specials.mastercard.de`, and it takes me to a 404 page. But, if I manually edit the URL and remove the "www." prefix in the address bar, the site works.

I haven't tried running a link checker on the site for a while, so I can't remember how many site links were possibly broken due to us assuming "https://" protocol and "www." subdomains for a breach Domain.

issues.title: Audit Postgres indexes
issues.body:
Index All The Things!

I'm trying to come up with a semi-comprehensive list of queries and indexes to try and identify any problem areas (and get a better sense of DB indexing w/ Postgres in general).

So far I've tried trolling through all the ./db/migrations/* and come up with a lost of anything marked `.primary()` or mentions `.index()`. Here's what I've come up with:

| TABLE.COLUMN | TYPE | NOTES
|:-------------|:-----|------
| `email_addresses.id` | .primary()
| `email_addresses.sha1` | .primary()
| `email_addresses.verification_token` | .unique()
| `subscribers.created_at` | .index()
| `subscribers.email` | .index()
| `subscribers.id` | .primary()
| `subscribers.sha1` | .index()
| `subscribers.verification_token` | .unique()
| `subscribers.verified` | .index()

I feel like I'm missing a few things here.

Renamed columns:

| OLD TABLE.COLUMN | NEW TABLE.COLUMN
|:----|:----
| `subscribers.email` | `subscribers.primary_email`
| `subscribers.sha1` | `subscribers.primary_sha1`
| `subscribers.verification_token` | `subscribers.primary_verification_token`
| `subscribers.verified` | `subscribers.primary_verified`

---

Next, I tried to find all queries with a `.where()`, `.whereIn()`, `.whereRaw()`, or `.andWhere()` reference (and did my best to de-knex them into a more readable SQL-esque format, then sorted and deduped):

- [ ] `email_addresses.email = $email`
- [x] `email_addresses.id = $emailId`
- [x] `email_addresses.sha1 in $hashes`
- [ ] `email_addresses.subscriber_id = $userId`
- [x] `email_addresses.verification_token = $token`
- [ ] `email_addresses.verified = true`
- [x] `subscribers.created_at < $expiredTimeStamp`
- [ ] `subscribers.fxa_uid = $fxaUID`
- [x] `subscribers.id = $id`
- [x] `subscribers.primary_email = $email`
- [x] `subscribers.primary_sha1 = $emailSha1`
- [x] `subscribers.primary_verification_token = $token`
- [x] `subscribers.primary_verified = true`

The ✅ above represent a match between a select.where() clause and the `.index()` or `.primary()` in the preceeding table. But doesn't take into account possible column renames.

I'm guessing this is inaccurate and full of holes, but hopefully a decent-adjacent starting point.

Some suggestions are:

1. Verify new tables/columns have appropriate indexes. Not sure how/if we can automate this, or how to test it. There was some Slack conversations about a "postgres EXPLAIN" command, but I haven't tried digging in yet.
1. Verify assets are minified (images, etc).
1. Verify latest breaches have logos.
1. Verify latest 100% (90%?) locales are enabled on production (w/ coordination w/ OPs whom I believe have to set the locales in some k8s config files somewhere).
1. \<other\>

issues.title: Evaluating the impact the Firefox account requirement has had on email addresses that were signed up to Firefox Monitor alerts before such requirement was put in place
issues.body:
Before the Firefox account requirement was added to Firefox Monitor I was monitoring a few of my email addresses using the previous sign up method (the one that closely resembles the current Have I Been Pwned "Notify me" feature).

Here's how it looked like: https://web.archive.org/web/20190302215900/https://monitor.firefox.com/

Once the Firefox account requirement (and later the ability to once again monitor multiple email addresses) was introduced I added my email addresses to Firefox Monitor one more time.

At this point I thought it'd try to unsubscribe the email addresses added to Firefox Monitor using the old method but found out it wasn't possible.
If I try to open one of the old unsubscribe URLs from a browser tab that's logged in to my Firefox account I currently get redirected to the Firefox Monitor Preferences page, while if I try the same thing from a browser tab that's not loggged in to my Firefox account I get the now famous message:

"Error
You must be signed in to your Firefox Account."

Does that mean that I don't need to worry? That my pre-Firefox account requirement breach notification subscriptions have been canceled as soon as I added the same email addresses to the now Firefox account-powered Firefox Monitor?

Or is this a bug and I'll be now getting 2 notifications for each data breach?

Regards.

issues.title: Add a .well-known/change-password route for chancing FxA password?
issues.body:
Ref #1112 

Q: Should https://monitor.firefox.com/.well-known/change-password work and redirect you to FxA change password form?

Currently https://accounts.firefox.com/.well-known/change-password cleverly redirects to https://accounts.firefox.com/settings/change_password, which is pretty cool.

We could potentially set up a /.well-known/change-password Express route which redirects to the FxA's .well-known/change-password route.

**PROS:** Probably more future-safe than trying to redirect to their /settings/change_password route directly (in the slight chance they change that endpoint in the future).
**CONS:** One extra redirect.

issues.title: The site can be misinterpreted as a breach of Firefox Account data
issues.body:
My native language doesn't have a concept of indefinite/definite articles in the grammar, so I don't pay much attention to them when reading English text. And therefore:

>  See if you’ve been part of an online data breach.

to me reads confusingly similar to:

>  See if you’ve been part of the (our) online data breach.

The headline sounds as if Mozilla itself (or Firefox Sync) had suffered a data breach.

The monitor site can be easily misinterpreted for Mozilla's own admission that Mozilla has leaked Firefox Account data (especially that Firefox Account is so prominently featured on the page). Equifax had set up such site when they've leaked their data.

(BTW: "Take back control" is a Brexit campaign slogan, so the second heading on this page is not great either.)

Please make it very clear that the monitor site is not about Firefox's password manager leaking passwords of the websites it manages.

The whole premise of this site is weird, because the origin of this data is unclear. Mozilla was not supposed to be collecting any login data, so suddenly knowing where my credentials went for the last 12 years is super creepy.

issues.title: [06-06-2019] Lighthouse results for dev server
issues.body:
**TL;DR:**
- **Performance** was usually yellow, but can be tricky to test since hitting the server again could give you better perf results (and this is a dev server).
- **Accessibility** was generally good, but a could use some tweaking on /breaches page.
- **Best Practices** looks misleading, as it's flagging our use of HTTP/1.1 vs HTTP/2 for loading resources, and an "unsafe" link to cross-origin destinations in the Mozilla footer link, and the fact that the dev server spews browser console errors hitting the FxA endpoint.
- **SEO** results were always great.

Also possibly worth noting was that I'm not sure how to automate or test Lighthouse scanning with pages behind forms, so I can't seemingly test the /scan endpoint performance.

issues.title: Logos on /scan endpoint aren't lazy loaded
issues.body:
## Steps to reproduce
0. Open Devtools Network monitor.
1. Go to https://monitor.firefox.com/
2. Enter your email address (test@test.com) and click "Check for breaches".
3. Check the number of requests in the Network monitor.

test@test.com was in 192 breaches, and the /scan endpoint attempts to load 195 images (about 1.0 MB), without the user even interacting with the page. The /breaches endpoint only loads 12 images (62 KB), with the rest being lazily loaded once they are within the viewport.

### Expected results
Lazy load images on the /scan page as well.

I just logged in via FxA to production https://monitor.firefox.com site and got the report email and noticed that we're only showing the top 2 compromised data categories, which can feel a bit misleading for the full report email.

Same with the logged in https://monitor.firefox.com/user/dashboard page. If you want to see the full list of compromised data, you need to go to each the /breach-details page for each individual breach.

Looks like the filtering is happening in 

https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/c25f2ab1b3f286e1fdd10abfef84610cf5cdc1af/template-helpers/breaches.js#L19-L33

![Your_Firefox_Monitor_report_-_peterdehaan_gmail_com_-_Gmail](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/557895/58501745-f977ae80-8139-11e9-841e-663204f98fbb.png)

issues.title: Check and set the breach categoryId once when loading breaches instead of at runtime
issues.body:
Currently [`getBreachDetail()`](https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/b6c5f1e97972ff1bb9f7ea366f3bbc0b81508ec3/template-helpers/breach-detail.js#L183) calls `getBreachCategory()` twice (and `getBreachCategory()` calls 1-5 `if` statements).

https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/6c5951f60e795af0e879d45ec54bbcb26c8f5f9b/template-helpers/breach-detail.js#L185-L186

Since breach data never changes after it is loaded, not sure if it'd be worth just doing the check once and adding the breach category in the `app.locals.breaches[]` array. Something like `breach.categoryId = getBreachCategory(breach);`

https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/b6c5f1e97972ff1bb9f7ea366f3bbc0b81508ec3/hibp.js#L81-L91

issues.title: No specific breach descriptions for Unverified breach, or Spam List breach
mspy breach is currently only breach without priority data classes
Replace breach logo images with favicons or other more uniformly squarish images.
issues.body: This lovely 'breach card' (see attached) has been designed for us to use everywhere on the site, but our current logos are unpredictably sized, often white (disappear on white backgrounds), and are often horizontally oriented (would appear very squished on this card). We need to replace our current logo images with something more uniform. Images must be 1.) large enough to look right on the breach detail pages, 2.) Small enough to not be "soul-crushing" and 3.) of approximately equal height and width. Favicons have been suggested. Tried so far: 1.) Scraping from "Google Favicon Snatcher" Result: Unusable, low quality, tiny images. Bad all around. 2.) Scraping from api.faviconkit.com (endpoints look like this: `https://api.faviconkit.com/www.breachDomain.com/192` where 192 can be subbed for whichever site-image size you're going for). Result: Got rate limited, but the images were mostly fantastic.

issues.title: Audit usage of {{ vs {{{ in .hbs templates
issues.body:
General observation, but I'm a bit confused about the usage of `{{` vs `{{{` in these templates. issues.title: The error " This email address is not subscribe to Firefox Monitor" is displayed even if the user didn't go through all the steps to unsubscribe
issues.body:
[Affected versions]:
- latest Beta 64.0b14

[Affected Platforms]:
- Ubuntu 18.04 x64

[Steps to reproduce]:
1. Navigate to https://stage.firefoxmonitor.nonprod.cloudops.mozgcp.net/
2. Sign up for Firefox Monitor and confirm your email.
3. From the report mail click on the unsubscribe link.
4. From the Unsubscribe from Firefox Monitor page click on "Unsubscribe" button.

[Expected result]:
- A page with the options why you want to unsubscribe from Firefox Monitor is displayed. 

[Actual result]:
- The error " This email address is not subscribe to Firefox Monitor" is displayed on the screen. 

[Regression]:
- Seems to be a an issue with the new GCP environment stage, since the issue is not repro on production (https://monitor.firefox.com/) and old stage (https://blurts-server.stage.mozaws.net/).

[Additional note]:
- The email report is sent. I just think that it's an issue of just not going through all the steps.

issues.title: When a user revokes Monitor from FXA, prompt to restore or delete data

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Issue describes an improvement or addition to the product.

issues.body:
See https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/pull/1452#discussion_r359656863 and https://github.com/mozilla/fxa/issues/3744 for full discussion.

Consensus is:


* If we get a 401 response to the request with our access token, we'll try to use our refresh token to get a fresh access token and use that to get the profile data
* If we get a 400 response to the request with our access token, with errno: 108, inform the user that Monitor has been revoked from their Firefox Account, and prompt them to either:
   * Reconnect Monitor to their FxA (Trigger the oauth flow again)
   * Delete Firefox Monitor from their account

issues.title: Add a doc w/ dates of when email alerts are sent out (starting with 2019-11-25)
issues.body: The instrumentation that was added to measure return visits to the Monitor site via breach email has had a noticeable impact on the FxA MAU timeseries, which is an important KPI. Going forward, starting with the first instrumented breach alert (2019-11-25), could we add a simple  document to the repo that is updated (preferably) before each new email breach that is sent? This would allow @jmccrosky to handle these dates as as regressor in his forecasting model, potentially allowing it produce more accurate MAU forecasts.  I think this could be a simple as a one-date-per-line doc, dates formatted YYYY-MM-DD (the dates will be pulled into the model automatically).

issues.title: Duplicate breach alert emails are sometimes sent

labels.name: defect
labels.description: Issue describes a defect that negatively impacts use.

issues.body: During the PDL breach load, some users reported duplicate breach alert emails. Need to investigate and debug. One user seems to have received 2 separate breach alerts to separate emails based on case-sensitivity. (hashes `548370b23a92e2f2d9766784ab3381643132ef80` and `30e1f57127a079f67e09eeccd6d4e1edf33f4a91`) - check to see that all our case-insensitive checks are applied thru-out the breach notification process. Another user seems to have received 2 separate breach alerts to the exact same email address, approx. 30m apart. Note: The bounce and complaint rates remained relatively constant during the load, so it does not look like the duplicates caused a spike of spam notifications.

issues.title: Accept email scan requests from www.mozilla.org
issues.body:
We would like to add an email input field to the Firefox What’s New Page "WNP" hosted on www.mozilla.org (www). When a user enters their email, we would like to send them straight to Firefox Monitor (monitor) scan results page for the email.

To fight against abusive bot scans on the Monitor scan endpoint, we use IP rate-limiting and check both a CSRF token and another encrypted token of our own implementation on the back-end. These tokens will also prevent these scan requests from mozilla.org.

So, we would need to add a way to authenticate scans coming from www.mozilla.org:

1. www and monitor both have a shared secret on the back-end
2. www WNP asks for a user’s email
3. www WNP puts the user’s email and a timestamp in the payload[1] of a JWT with an hmac sha256 using the shared secret
4. www WNP sends the user to monitor. with the JWT in a url (or POST?) param (or Authorization header?)
5. monitor verifies the JWT, retrieves the user’s email, performs a scan, and shows the results

[1] proposed JWT payload claims:
```
{
  "iss": "www.mozilla.org",
  "aud": "monitor.firefox.com",
  "iat": "2019-10-22T00:00:00Z"
  "email": "test@mailinator.com"
}
```
Where:
* `iat` ("Issued At") contains the timestamp when the email was entered on www.mozilla.org
* `email` contains the email address entered by the user

issues.title: Clean out and prevent duplicate subscriber records
issues.body:
To keep UX simple and prevent account enumeration, we have not prevented duplicate subscriber records. (When breaches are loaded, we [only send 1 email alert to each subscriber.](https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/bf446223ada3baeaf6ce2b3725aefa58d525206d/controllers/hibp.js#L53))

But, we can keep the UX simple and prevent account enumeration if we change `verifyEmailHash` to check for an existing verified subscriber record with the same email address. If it finds one, it can simply delete the unverified record and return the same response to the user: "Confirmed. You are subscribed"

Note: when we implement this, we should also remove existing duplicates.

issues.title: Make eligible for HSTS preloading
issues.body:
See https://hstspreload.org/?domain=monitor.firefox.com

In our code, we need to add preload and max-age=31536000 to Strict-Transport-Security header.

We also need to watch https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1494431 and https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1494664 to see when *.firefox.com is ready for domain-wide preloading inclusion.

issues.title: Implement error codes
issues.body:
To help with error handling and mozlog, we should implement app-specific error codes & messages. E.g.,

`controllers/hibp.js`:
```js
const HIBP_ERRORS = {
  "100": {code: 100, message: "HIBP notify endpoint requires valid authorization token."},
  "101": {code: 101, message: "HIBP notify endpoint requires breachName, hashPrefix, and hashSuffixes."},
  "102": {code: 102, message: "Unrecognized breach."},
}
```
Then we could export to make them available to other code ...
```js
module.exports = {
  notify,
  breaches,
  HIBP_ERRORS
}
```
and we can `mozlog` e.g., ... 
`server.js`:
```js
log.error("error", HIBP_ERRORS.100}
```
or in `middleware.js` ...
```js
log.error("error", HIBP_ERRORS.102, stack: err.stack});
```

issues.title: Resolved/Unresolved status of the breach is not changed after clicking the Back button of the browser
issues.body:
[Affected versions]:

Firefox 72.0.2 and Safari

[Affected Platforms]:

MacOS 10.14

[Steps to reproduce]:

1. Navigate to https://monitor-v2.herokuapp.com/
2. Log into a Firefox Monitor account that monitors multiple email addresses
3. Find a breach that is common for more than one email address (3 in my case) and click anywhere on its surface.
4. In the "Marking this breach as resolved" section, click on "Mark as Resolved" button only for one email account.

The status of the breach should be changed into Resolved.

[Actual result]:

Page is not refreshed and status is not changed.

[Additional Info]:

The same thing happens  when you "Undo" the breach.

issues.title: Lazy load breach logos when doing a /scan?
issues.body:
This may be a bit of a stretch, but I noticed while doing a scan of "test@gmail.com" that there are 136 breaches, and we load all the logos immediately (151 network requests | 1.5 MB transferred | Finished: 5.85 s | DOMContentLoaded: 1.79 s), even though only 4 breach logos are immediately visible, and the remaining 132 logos are hidden behind the "Show all" button.

Not sure if we want to try [lazy loading](https://www.sitepoint.com/five-techniques-lazy-load-images-website-performance/) those 132 images so we aren't making all those network requests up front.

Looking at the network log a bit more, it seems like 140/151 requests are for images (962 KB of 1.5 MB total; the FiraSans-*.woff fonts take up a fairly significant 333 KB of the total page size). But if we look at 962 KB from 140 images, that's roughly 6.87 KB per image, or very roughly 907 KB of images which may not need to be loaded immediately).

Currently error-429.html is just an expertly crafted HTML document. Which means if we change our headers/footers/markup, we'll need to do it in two places now, so the 429 page stays in sync (if we care).

issues.title: Change breach notification email image to real image
issues.body:
Noticed this while testing the breach notification on stage ...

![screen shot 2018-09-26 at 3 53 07 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71928/46108734-5898b400-c1a4-11e8-8a5d-e68e18d403d3.png)

It may take some trickery, but I think we can do this:

1. Change the img `src` to be what the *real* breach image url will be when we upload it
2. Configure nginx to default to serve `/public/img/email_images/missing-logo-icon.png` instead of `404`s from `/public/img/logos`

That way, users who open the email before we upload the breach image will see `missing-logo-icon.png`, but users who open the email after we upload the breach image will see the breach image.

issues.title: Remove breach logos?
issues.body:
Unpopular Opinion: The breach logos don't really add much to the site experience, but do cause oodles of headaches and babysitting.

Should we continue monitoring new breaches and reactively adding optimized logos, or should we abandon logos on the site to make it easier on ourselves, or is there a clever option C?

Discuss.

---

```sh
du -sh public/img/logos/
# 2.5M	public/img/logos/
```

# USAGE

## 1. [Homepage](https://monitor.firefox.com/)

![Firefox_Monitor](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/557895/69888173-5eee5880-129f-11ea-998b-5d988cc12f3b.png)

![Firefox_Monitor](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/557895/69888286-dd4afa80-129f-11ea-91a7-de152679ac39.png)

---

## 4. [User Dashboard](https://monitor.firefox.com/user/dashboard) page

![Firefox_Monitor](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/557895/69888339-2bf89480-12a0-11ea-9622-df7af4533765.png)

Logos also appear on the /user/dashboard page after you've signed in, but I think it might be the same breach card template that is used on the /breaches page.

---

issues.title: Add ability to mark breach as "resolved"
issues.body:
Once I’ve addressed a breach, I want to be able to check-off (dismiss) the associated breach alert within dashboard (eg checked off as “done”).

## Acceptance criteria
- [ ] Should be able to resolve/dismiss a breach (from the breach detail page)
- [ ] Should be able to revisit resolved/dismissed breaches from an archive or collapsed state
- [ ] From the breach detail, I should be able to see what emails are affected by the breach
- [ ] I should see an indicator on the dashboard of progress made (ie # of breaches resolved/# of total breaches)
- [ ] The feature should encourage/celebrate resolving breaches, both as individual breaches are resolved and if all breaches are resolved (delight)
- [ ] Should give people another option for taking action for "data aggregator breaches", since changing passwords or deleting accounts is not effective. 
- [ ] Should incite surprise and delight when taking actions
- [ ] Should instill confidence that I know what to do next to protect myself 

## Other considerations
- [ ] Improve the core recommendations logic so that we provide the right steps for effective remediation based on the types of data compromised
- [ ] Should be able to highlight associated security tips (ie not just changing the breached account password but also anywhere else I use that same password)
- [ ] Should promote Lockwise + Firefox for further automation of resolving breaches in the browser - to be explored in #1223
- [ ] Measure the success or failure of resolving breaches via telemetry
- [ ] Mitigate the relationship between about:logins breaches in Firefox and the dashboard of Monitor; if someone resolves in one location, update the other accordingly (https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1593095) 
- [ ] We may need to reconsider our "show 4 breaches and hide the rest" logic for overflow scenarios, in lieu of the need to 'hide' resolved breaches

## Recommendations Logic Revamp
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1MlRHSs5PVEO0baDduWLTBJWWSQuwOCVZewhPuDN3ZKE/edit?usp=sharing

## Visual design
https://mozilla.invisionapp.com/share/QPUNSW95VU8#/screens

## Engineering Tasks
### Back-end
- [ ] Add a `breaches_resolved` JSON column to `subscribers` table to store data like:
```
[
  {"email_address": <primary_email_address>, "recency_indices":[0,2]},
  {"email_address": <another_email_address>, "recency_indices":[1]},
]
```
- [ ] Augment `bundleVerifiedEmails` function with logic to add properties to the `emailEntry` objects:
  - `"resolved": true|false`
  - `"recency_index": Number`
- [ ] Add an HTTP POST endpoint for `/user/breach/resolution` that accepts `subscriber_id`, (optional) `email_address_id`, and `recency_index` and:
```
SELECT * FROM subscribers s, email_addresses ea WHERE s.id = subscriber_id
const breachesResolvedJSON = subscriber.breaches_resolved
if `email_address_id`
  emailAddress = email_address.email
else
  emailAddress = subscribers.primary_email
breachesResolvedJSON[emailAddress].recency_indices.push(recencyIndex)
UPDATE subscribers SET breaches_resolved = breachesResolvedJSON
```
### Front-end
**Breach Detail Pages:**
- [ ]  Add/modify existing logic to show recommendations based on a breach's exposed data classes instead of the breach "type".
- [ ] Add [new UI](https://mozilla.invisionapp.com/share/QPUNSW95VU8#/screens/391639733) related to resolving breaches. 

#### New UI:
- [ ] Add new "Breach Successfully Resolved!" templates and logic for determining which message should be surfaced. (Question for later: What happens when ALL breaches have been resolved?)
- [ ] Add "New in Firefox Monitor..." blurb when zero breaches have been resolved and determine how long this blurb persists if a user has signed in a few times and hasn't resolved any breaches.
- [ ] Add Progress Bar UI

**Misc. Dashboard Updates:**
- [ ] Update Breach Summary callouts to include numbers for resolved breaches and passwords.
- [ ] Update Breach Cards: 
  - Update card UI for "New" and "Resolved" states. 
  - Figure out how to handle any potential spacing conflicts between long breach titles and longer translations of "Resolved" - especially on mobile.
  - Show "Resolve this breach" link in /dashboard breach cards. 
- [ ] Swap section headline string in /dashboard
- [ ] Add UI for hiding resolved breaches.

issues.title: Recommend specific tools to help users enable 2FA on their accounts
issues.body:
Echoing the comment I just made in another thread (https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/issues/463#issuecomment-427620305) I think that it is incredibly important to recommend and link to specific tools/services that people can use to make their accounts more secure.

Monitor recommends that people enable 2FA on their accounts, but currently it does not give any guidance about how to actually do that. There are many good resources whose goal is to help average internet users do just that. I think Monitor should link people directly to those tools so that there is a higher chance they will follow through and enable 2FA on their accounts.

1. [2FA Notifier](https://2fanotifier.org)
2. [TurnOn2FA](https://www.turnon2fa.com/)
3. [twofactorauhorg](twofactorauth.org)

I am the developer and maintainer of [2FA Notifier](https://2fanotifier.org), an open source browser extension for Firefox and Chrome that notifies people anytime they visit a website that supports 2FA. Plus, it helps people actually enable 2FA by linking them directly to the documentation for how to setup 2FA on that site. For more details, check out [an article](https://www.allthingsauth.com/2018/09/24/introducing-2fa-notifier-how-to-get-more-internet-users-to-enable-2fa-on-their-accounts/) I recently wrote about 2FA Notifier and the problem it solves that was published on the Okta Developer Blog.

I would love to see 2FA Notifier recommended as a tool to help people enable 2FA on their accounts.

issues.title: Make it more obvious that the "basic" web scan doesn't include the full results
issues.body:
Ref: #472 

Currently if I search a email address with zero breaches, the website tells me:

> **So far, so good**
> Your account did not appear in our basic scan. That's good news, but data breaches can happen any time and there is still more you can do. Subscribe to Firefox Monitor for a full report, alerts when new breaches happen, and tips on protecting your passwords.

And the output from a scan with breached accounts says:

> **This might be a problem**
> Your accounts were compromised in the following breaches.

I believe in both cases we should probably make it more obvious that the website doesn't include sensitive breach information and other results that are included in the full email report.
I'll file a separate issue for the UI/UX team to come up with some additional words to make our intentions/results more transparent.

issues.title: FxA Optimization for Existing Accountholders

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Issue describes an improvement or addition to the product.

issues.body:
Currently, when a user types an email address into the email field on our home page and checks for breaches, we do not check and see if that email address is associated with a Firefox Account. This creates a hole in our engagement potential; if we were to identify and instead route someone through the authentication funnel, we could provide additional value to the signed in user (resolving a breach, sensitive breach results, etc) rather than just the basic breach results currently being returned to them. 

My proposal would be to perform the check once someone hits the "check for breaches" button and if there is an account, present an overlay (similar to the breach resolution completed state) informing the user that they already have a Firefox account, and directing them towards the Sign In flow. We pass the email address automagically, ask for their password, and then route them to the Dashboard as though they had intended to sign in all along. (Note: there will be a portion of users that have Firefox accounts but have never used Monitor... this flow approach implies that they would need to understand the relationship between their Firefox Account and a property that uses it... I think it's an acceptable risk to deliver additional value and more accurately measure engagement of FxA users)

InVision: https://mozilla.invisionapp.com/share/RGRIETZ7NAJ#/408892450_Account_Found_Overlay
Zeplin: https://zpl.io/br6e7pD

Some of this work may need to be coordinated with Alex Davis and FxA, but logging the request here for now.

issues.title: Only offer 2FA advice on domains that support 2FA on breach-details page?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Issue describes an improvement or addition to the product.

issues.body:
I was randomly looking at the https://monitor.firefox.com/breach-details/EuropaJobs#breach-detail breach for a different bug, and noticed that it suggests that I "Set up two-factor authentication (2FA)", but from the look of the linked https://twofactorauth.org/ site, that domain (europa.jobs) doesn't support 2FA.

A bit of a rabbit hole later, and I inferred that I can fetch the domains from the .yml files in https://github.com/2factorauth/twofactorauth/tree/master/_data/.
Next, I wrote https://github.com/pdehaan/2fa-domains which scrapes and aggregates the twofactorauth \_data files.
Next next, I wrote https://github.com/pdehaan/blurts-2fa which compares the HIBP domain list to the 2FA domain list, and it looks like possibly only ~~29~~ 20 (out of of the 426 known HIBP breached sites) might support 2FA.

~~Although I might have a medium bug in my logic based on the fact that https://twofactorauth.org/#transport shows 45 domains, but only 2 seemingly support 2FA, so I should be filtering the scraped .yml files and making sure each  website in https://github.com/2factorauth/twofactorauth/blob/master/_data/transport.yml has a `tfa` key so we know the site actually supports 2FA.~~ Fixed.

Updated list of HIBP+2FA domains:

```
833 2FA domains
426 breaches
20 breached domains have 2FA

issues.title: When a user revokes Monitor from FXA, prompt to restore or delete data

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Issue describes an improvement or addition to the product.

issues.body:
See https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/pull/1452#discussion_r359656863 and https://github.com/mozilla/fxa/issues/3744 for full discussion.

Consensus is:


* If we get a 401 response to the request with our access token, we'll try to use our refresh token to get a fresh access token and use that to get the profile data
* If we get a 400 response to the request with our access token, with errno: 108, inform the user that Monitor has been revoked from their Firefox Account, and prompt them to either:
   * Reconnect Monitor to their FxA (Trigger the oauth flow again)
   * Delete Firefox Monitor from their account

issues.title: Audit our usage of sha1() and .toLowerCase() when scanning emails.

labels.name: defect
labels.description: Issue describes a defect that negatively impacts use.

labels.name: effort-S
labels.description: Expected to take less than a week for engineering to complete.

issues.body: We occasionally run into issues (most recently, #1461) stemming from our usage of `sha1()` and `.toLowerCase()` causing false negative scan results when the scanned email address contains uppercase letters. Let's audit/standardize/demystify/betterify the `sha1()`/`.toLowerCase()` steps in all the places we scan emails so that we don't unintentionally confuse someone or give them a false sense of security by providing incorrect scan results in the future.

labels.name: defect
labels.description: Issue describes a defect that negatively impacts use.

issues.body: During the PDL breach load, some users reported duplicate breach alert emails. Need to investigate and debug. One user seems to have received 2 separate breach alerts to separate emails based on case-sensitivity. (hashes `548370b23a92e2f2d9766784ab3381643132ef80` and `30e1f57127a079f67e09eeccd6d4e1edf33f4a91`) - check to see that all our case-insensitive checks are applied thru-out the breach notification process. Another user seems to have received 2 separate breach alerts to the exact same email address, approx. 30m apart. Note: The bounce and complaint rates remained relatively constant during the load, so it does not look like the duplicates caused a spike of spam notifications.

issues.body:
I had two email addresses (gmail & mailbox), both in my FF account and in Monitor. I have changed my primary email address in my Firefox account (from gmail to mailbox).

After applying this change in my FF account, I refreshed the preferences page of Monitor to see if the primary address would update there too, but that didn't happen.

I logged out from Monitor, and logged in again (via FF account), with my mailbox account (as it's the primary one now). I entered Monitor, but my secondary (gmail) address is no longer listed. This makes me assume seems I am in a different, new Monitor account.

To verify this assumption, I changed again my FF primary email address, logged out of Monitor, and logged in again via FF (using my primary email address). Voila, there my gmail (intended secondary) shows up again.

Am I indeed correct with my assumption? Isn't this a security risk (an unused account remaining available on Monitor until eternity)? How can I delete my unused, gmail-as-primary account from Monitor?

issues.title: After you reset the password, the FM page is automatically refreshed and you are logged in

labels.name: defect
labels.description: Issue describes a defect that negatively impacts use.

issues.body:
[Affected versions]:
- Firefox 65.0.1

[Affected Platforms]:
- Windows 10 x64
- macOS 10.13
- Ubuntu 18.04 x64

[Steps to reproduce]:
1. Navigate to  http://stage.firefoxmonitor.nonprod.cloudops.mozgcp.net
2. Click on the “Sign in” button.
3. In the sign in page click on “Forgot password?”
4. Take all the steps to reset your password.

[Expected result]:
- A refresh should be required and the user has to type the new password so that he can be logged in. 

[Actual result]:
- After you reset the password, the FM page is automatically refreshed and you are logged in.

[Regression]:
- N/A

issues.title: Move server files into a subdirectory
issues.body:
Just a weird thought while looking through the directory structure, but currently we have a bunch of code amongst the documentation, and numerous config files.

Not sure if moving a bunch of the root-level files and folders into some nested "src/" folder would make things easier to find, and possibly make it easier to optimize some CSS/JS/SVG/PNG files before deploying into some "dist/" folder or something.

Initially, I was thinking maybe moving the following files/folders may make sense:

- __controllers/**__
- __db/**__
- __public/**__
- __routes/**__
- __views/**__
- app-constants.js
- email-utils.js
- hbs-helpers.js
- hibp.js
- middleware.js
- server.js
- sha1-utils.js

That'd still leave the following files in the root directory:

- __loadtests/**__
- __scripts/**__
- __src/**__ (assuming we move the files above into a new **src/** directory)
- __tests/**__
- .dockerignore
- .env-dist
- .eslintignore
- .eslintrc.js
- .gitignore
- .htmllintrc
- .npmignore
- .stylelintrc
- .travis.yml
- Dockerfile
- LICENSE
- README.md
- api.md (probably kill this file)
- circle.yml (ref: #246; "Update to CircleCI v2 API")
- package-lock.json
- package.json

Of course, this would be pretty disruptive refactoring, so maybe not worth the effort/headache.

issues.title: Add Lighthouse auditing script?
issues.body:
https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/

It's a good little deploy check, but not sure how much we want to integrate it.

I've been hacking around with the latest v3-alpha branch and this seems to work OK:

```sh
$ npm i lighthouse@next -g
$ lighthouse https://fx-breach-alerts.herokuapp.com/ --quiet --chrome-flags="--headless" --view --disable-device-emulation
```

Here's the results w/ device (Nexus 5X) emulation:

![lighthouse_report_-_mobile](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/557895/40443836-5e6ab9f4-5e7c-11e8-9353-a4e05e4f2b45.png)

---

And the results w/ device emulation disabled:

![lighthouse_report_-_desktop](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/557895/40443890-8c5554c8-5e7c-11e8-9200-9b5c62263de2.png)

---

I haven't figured out how to disable specific "suites" (like "Progressive Web App") via the CLI yet.
I think at a minimum, it may be interesting to try adding [**lighthouse**](http://npm.im/lighthouse) to package.json scripts and this would just be some manual audit process we do while developing to try and squash a few a11y and SEO nits.

issues.title: Updated Copy for Security Tips Page
issues.body:
Security tips to protect yourself from hackers blurb |  
-- | --
Updated Copy ✅ | Outdated Copy ❌
Finding out you were part of one usually includes a long list of compromised information, such as your password, username, and email address. | Finding out you were part of one usually includes a laundry list compromised information, such as your password, username, and email address.
**Understand how hackers work** |  
Updated Copy ✅ | Outdated Copy ❌
The hackers responsible for data breaches usually start by targeting companies, rather than specific individuals. | The hackers responsible for data breaches start by targeting companies, not specific individuals.
That’s why cyber criminals often target massive companies with millions of users. | That’s why cyber criminals target massive companies with millions of users.
Then they steal or copy as much personal information as possible. | Then they steal or copy as much personal information as possible that lives in users’ online accounts.
We don’t always know what they intend to do with the data, but usually they will try to find a way to profit from it. The effects on you might not be immediate. | We don’t always know what they intend to do with the data, but usually they will find a way to profit from it. The effects to your online account might not be immediate.
All sorts of data can be valuable in some way because it can be sold on the dark web for a profit or kept for some future use. | All sorts of data can be valuable in some way because it can be sold on the dark web for a profit.
Common passwords make a hacker’s work easy. | What makes a password easy to guess.
Hackers aren’t actually guessing people’s passwords. To crack into accounts, they use automated programs that enter hundreds of popular passwords in just a few seconds. That’s why it’s important to avoid using the same passwords that everyone else does. | If hackers can get a list of email addresses from a data breach, they already have a good start. All they have to do is pick their website of choice and try these emails with the most popular passwords. Chances are, they’ll be able to get into quite a few accounts. So don’t use any of these 100 Worst Passwords of 2018.
**What to do after a data breach** |  
Updated Copy ✅ | Outdated Copy ❌
Many breaches expose emails and passwords, but some do include sensitive financial information. If your bank account or credit card numbers were included in a breach, alert your bank to possible fraud | Most breaches only expose emails and passwords, but some do include sensitive financial information. If your bank account or credit card numbers were included in a breach, alert your your bank to possible fraud.
**How to create strong passwords** |  
Updated Copy ✅ | Outdated Copy ❌
SECURITY TIP | SECURITY TIP:
According to a [study conducted by Google](**https://techland.time.com/2013/08/08/google-reveals-the-10-worst-password-ideas/?iid=biz-article-mostpop2**), passwords that contain the following information are considered insecure because they’re easy to figure out. NOTE: `study conducted by Google` is missing the link: https://techland.time.com/2013/08/08/google-reveals-the-10-worst-password-ideas/?iid=biz-article-mostpop2. | According to a study conducted by Google, passwords that contain the following information are considered insecure because they’re easy to figure out.
The word “Password,” or any variation of it. That includes P@assword! | The word “Password”
**Password do's and don'ts** |  
Updated Copy ✅ | Outdated Copy ❌
Do use different passwords everywhere. Password managers and many browsers can generate secure and unique passwords. | _New content. Should be number 1 under do._
Don’t use variations of the same password for different accounts. | _New content. Should be number 1 under don't_
Don’t use the word “password,” or any variation of it. “P@ssword!” is just as easy for hackers to guess. | Don’t use the word “password,” or any combination of it. “P@ssword!” is just as easy for hackers to guess.
Do intersperse numbers, symbols, and special characters throughout. | Do use a combination of upper- and lower-case letters, numbers, and symbols.
**REMOVE THIS CONTENT:** Do create unique and complex passwords for every site. | _Remove this content_
**REMOVE THIS CONTENT** Don't use the same password everywhere. | _Remove this content_
**Steps to take to protect your identity online** |  
Updated Copy ✅ | Outdated Copy ❌
Tips for keeping all your online accounts secure | Tips for keeping all your online accounts secure:
SECURITY TIP | SECURITY TIP:
Classic signs of a suspicious email | Know the classic signs of a suspicious email.
Seems especially urgent or time-critical | _New content. Should be number 2 under Classic signs of a suspicious email._
SECURITY TIP | SECURITY TIP:
How to create strong passwords | How to create strong passwords.
SECURITY TIP | SECURITY TIP:
Still wary of password managers? What’s most important is that you use different passwords everywhere. To remember them, write down your passwords and store them in a safe place that only you have access to. | _New Security Tip. Should be the last piece of content in this section_
**5 myths about password managers** |  
Updated Copy ✅ | Outdated Copy ❌
Your passwords are securely stored inside. | Your passwords are securely stored inside it.
Only stores encrypted versions of your credentials and data on their servers | Encrypts all your data
No tool can completely guarantee your online safety. | No privacy tool can completely guarantee your online safety.
**Take further steps to protect your identity** |  
Updated Copy ✅ | Outdated Copy ❌
When significant data breaches happen where high-risk data is at stake, there’s often talk about credit reports. Some companies may even be required to provide credit monitoring as part of its breach notification requirements. | When big data breaches happen, there’s immediately a lot of talk about credit reports.
Each bureau may have slightly different information, which is why it’s important to check all three regularly. | Each may have slightly different information, which is why it’s important to check all three regularly.
Checking your report does not impact your score in any way. | And checking your report does not impact your score in any way.
You have a right to correct any inaccurate information on your record with the credit bureau. | Look for accounts or addresses you don't recognize or any information that is inaccurate.
If anything looks strange or is incorrect, contact the credit bureau immediately to begin a dispute. Instructions for how to initiate corrections can be found on your report. It’s important not to let inaccuracies linger as they may lower your score or be difficult to clear later. If you are concerned that you might be a victim of identity theft, report it and get help from the Federal Trade Commision at identitytheft.gov. | _New content. Add after last bullet that ends in `These do not affect your score.`_

issues.title: Security terms glossary

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Issue describes an improvement or addition to the product.

issues.body:
When I'm reading about breaches and security tips, I want to better understand the terms being used (eg credential stuffing) without leaving the context of the breach or the advice.

## Acceptance criteria
- [ ] Should offer easy to understand explanations for the terms:
   - [ ] credential stuffing
   - [ ] data breach
   - [ ] sensitive website breach
   - [ ] master password
- [ ] Should offer these definitions without removing the user out of the context of their reading

issues.title: Password Do's and Don'ts
issues.body:
Revisit Password do's and dont's. From @groovecoder:

> “Change letters to numbers or special characters”, “combination of upper- and lower-case letters, numbers, and symbols”, “spread various numbers and characters throughout your password”

> I understand they are essentially the opposite of the corresponding “Don’t”s, but they are also password advice that makes passwords harder for humans to remember without making them (much) harder for computers to crack.

> In the context of *all* the do’s and dont’s, those particular do’s aren’t bad. Just on their own they’re not great.

On the topic of pw managers:

> But I encounter a *lot* of not-digital-savvy attendees who are scared of password managers.

> To most of them I say:

> • Start using different longer passwords everywhere
> • It’s okay to write them down in a safe place (wallet, pin-protected phone, etc.) so long as you know to “freak out” if that safe place is ever lost.

issues.title: Localize breach descriptions?
Recommend specific tools to help users enable 2FA on their accounts
issues.body:
Echoing the comment I just made in another thread (https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/issues/463#issuecomment-427620305) I think that it is incredibly important to recommend and link to specific tools/services that people can use to make their accounts more secure.

Monitor recommends that people enable 2FA on their accounts, but currently it does not give any guidance about how to actually do that. There are many good resources whose goal is to help average internet users do just that. I think Monitor should link people directly to those tools so that there is a higher chance they will follow through and enable 2FA on their accounts.

1. [2FA Notifier](https://2fanotifier.org)
2. [TurnOn2FA](https://www.turnon2fa.com/)
3. [twofactorauhorg](twofactorauth.org)

I am the developer and maintainer of [2FA Notifier](https://2fanotifier.org), an open source browser extension for Firefox and Chrome that notifies people anytime they visit a website that supports 2FA. Plus, it helps people actually enable 2FA by linking them directly to the documentation for how to setup 2FA on that site. For more details, check out [an article](https://www.allthingsauth.com/2018/09/24/introducing-2fa-notifier-how-to-get-more-internet-users-to-enable-2fa-on-their-accounts/) I recently wrote about 2FA Notifier and the problem it solves that was published on the Okta Developer Blog.

I would love to see 2FA Notifier recommended as a tool to help people enable 2FA on their accounts.

issues.title: Make it more obvious that the "basic" web scan doesn't include the full results
issues.body:
Ref: #472 

Currently if I search a email address with zero breaches, the website tells me:

> **So far, so good**
> Your account did not appear in our basic scan. That's good news, but data breaches can happen any time and there is still more you can do. Subscribe to Firefox Monitor for a full report, alerts when new breaches happen, and tips on protecting your passwords.

And the output from a scan with breached accounts says:

> **This might be a problem**
> Your accounts were compromised in the following breaches.

I believe in both cases we should probably make it more obvious that the website doesn't include sensitive breach information and other results that are included in the full email report.
I'll file a separate issue for the UI/UX team to come up with some additional words to make our intentions/results more transparent.

issues.title: More technical detail please
issues.body:
I understand the basics of how the account lookup works by talking to groovecoder, but there's nothing on the site that explains the technical details. My grandmother may not need that level of detail, but if I recommend this site to a client they should be able to review the process of what's exactly is being done. 

I'd suggest adding a simple link on the page somewhere that says something like "How this works" or "Technical Details" and then outline the process. Here are a few relevant data points off the top of my head:

1. What you're doing with the addresses, how they're being used, stored, etc, what exactly is the user signing up for when they provide their address. 
2. Where the compromised data comes from, how extensive it is, how recent it is, etc.
3. What the relationship is with HIBP, what access does it have to the provided addresses, what's the retention policy.
4. For the alerts, how often will that be checked, does mozilla send account data to HIBP regularly, or are the updates checked some other way, etc.

Some of that detail is probably also necessary for GDPR & other compliance requirements. folks have to affirmatively consent to specific use-cases for their data, and have to understand what they're consenting to.

issues.body:
Affected versions]:

[Affected Platforms]:
- Windows 10 x64
- Windows 7 x64
- macOS 10.13
- Ubuntu 18.04 x64

[Steps to reproduce]:
1. Navigate to https://blurts-server-review.herokuapp.com/
2. Without signing in, enter any email address (ex. john@mailinator.com) and click on "Check for Breaches" button.
3. Click on any of the breaches.
4. Zoom in and observe the behaviour.
5. Select "Zoom Text Only" (Menu bar -> View -> Zoom -> Zoom Text Only).
6. Zoom in and observe behaviour. 

[Expected result]:
- The banners has the same format. 

[Actual result]:
- The banners are different. 

[Regression]:
- N/A

[Additional Info]:

issues.body:
When I learn about a breach, I want help remediating the impacts of that breach and to prevent them from happening in the future. This is where Firefox generally can help with a plethora of privacy and security options.

## Requirements
- If no other, higher ranking criteria are met, show this
- Should have UTM parameters to track click events (how many people are going to which location)

Child of #1223

issues.title: Display promo for Firefox Mobile

labels.name: effort-M

issues.body:
When I learn about a breach, I want help remediating the impacts of that breach and to prevent them from happening in the future. This is where Firefox generally can help, with privacy settings in both desktop and mobile.

## Requirements
- Display on the breach detail page when someone is already authenticated, and not using Firefox mobile
- If on desktop, should prompt to download (send to device widget?)
- If on mobile, should route them to the appropriate app store listing for Firefox
- Should have UTM parameters to track click events (how many people are going to which location)

Child of #1223

issues.body:
When I learn about a breach that involves my passwords, I want help remediating the impacts of that breach and to prevent them from happening in the future. This is where Lockwise can help.

## Requirements
- Display on the breach detail page when someone is already authenticated, using Firefox, and on a breach where password has been compromised
- If on Firefox desktop, should route to about:logins (depends on #1450)
- Should have UTM parameters to track click events (how many people are going to which location)
- Option: Directly open the menu with the logins option highlighted from the Monitor website

Future consideration: introduce the mobile discovery path

Child of #1223

issues.title: Add supported locales to stage/production /__version__ endpoint
issues.body:
Ref #609 and #1245 PR and https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/pull/1245#issuecomment-538105086

Currently the production [`/__version__`](https://monitor.firefox.com/__version__) endpoint has the following:

```js
{
  "commit": "6280822d4db00ed58a3d149e5abd51a3df443c83", 
  "version": "v9.0.2",
  "source": "https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server",
  "build": "https://circleci.com/gh/mozilla/blurts-server/7318"
}
```

But the Heroku [`/__version__`](https://fx-breach-alerts.herokuapp.com/__version__) endpoint also has a jazzy `languages` string of supported locales:

```js
{
  "commit": "46fc20a687a39fa4588ec1934f80791cb9ed8222",
  "version": "46fc20a687a39fa4588ec1934f80791cb9ed8222",
  "source": "https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server",
  "languages": "cs,cy,da,de,en,en-CA,es-AR,es-CL,es-ES,es-MX,fr,fy-NL,hu,ia,id,it,ja,kab,ms,nl,pt-BR,pt-PT,ro,ru,sk,sl,sq,sv-SE,tr,uk,vi,zh-CN,zh-TW"
}
```

It'd be great if we can find a way to add the "languages" string/array to the stage/production endpoints as well so QA/l10n can know exactly which languages are supported. I know we have a Top Secret OPs repo (URL redacted) with configs and the `firefoxMonitorSupportedLocales` array, but not everybody has security clearance access to that repo, and somehow shimming the `firefoxMonitorSupportedLocales` config into the `/__version__` endpoint would solve that issue and give l10n people a definitive way of seeing what locale support is currently in production, and know if the locale list is stale or not.

/cc @flodolo @Micheletto

issues.title: Localize breach descriptions?
A few references to "Firefox Monitor" in the .ftl files
issues.body:
Uber nit warning: It looks like a few *.ftl files are using the "Firefox Monitor" string directly instead of using `{ -product-name }`. Not a huge deal, but just depends on how much we want to keep these in line...

---

I was looking at https://monitor.firefox.com/__version__ which says our current deployed SHA on production is f97777d077683eb3e573928be606e3430bf5e5e4 (diff: https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/compare/f97777d077683eb3e573928be606e3430bf5e5e4...master). Looks like we've had 131 commits in the past 18 days since our last production deployment.

Anyways, while quickly scanning the diffs, I noticed this change, https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/commit/74d3f8583dc13fdd26fadca16396998bb26716d6, which seems to have _suspiciously_ changed `{ -product-name }` variable to `Firefox Monitor` literal.

```diff
-    Potvrďte své přihlášení ke službě { -product-name } do 24 hodin od odeslání tohoto e-mailu.
+    Potvrďte své přihlášení ke službě Firefox Monitor do 24 hodin od odeslání tohoto e-mailu.
...
- report-subhead-found-breaches = Toto je vaše kompletní hlášení ze služby { -product-name }, které obsahuje všechny známé úniky dat s touto e-mailovou adresou.
+ report-subhead-found-breaches = Toto je vaše kompletní hlášení ze služby Firefox Monitor, které obsahuje všechny známé úniky dat s touto e-mailovou adresou.
```

Being the curious lad I am, I set out to try and find out how many other locales are potentially embedding the product name directly in strings. I think this is semi-accurate (instances of "Firefox Monitor" which aren't a comment or the `-product-name` value specifically), and it does seem like there are a couple instances of "Firefox Monitor" embedded in the core ./locales/en/email-strings.ftl file, which is a bit suspicious:

https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/404b046388b63c15956bb0dc69f345761c57895b/locales/en/email-strings.ftl#L6-L8

https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/404b046388b63c15956bb0dc69f345761c57895b/locales/en/email-strings.ftl#L48-L49

$ git grep "Firefox Monitor" locales/ | grep -v ":#" | grep -v ":-product-name = "

issues.title: Display promo for Firefox Mobile

labels.name: effort-M
labels.description: Expected to take a week for engineering to complete.

issues.body:
When I learn about a breach, I want help remediating the impacts of that breach and to prevent them from happening in the future. This is where Firefox generally can help, with privacy settings in both desktop and mobile.

## Requirements
- Display on the breach detail page when someone is already authenticated, and not using Firefox mobile
- If on desktop, should prompt to download (send to device widget?)
- If on mobile, should route them to the appropriate app store listing for Firefox
- Should have UTM parameters to track click events (how many people are going to which location)

Child of #1223

issues.title: Implement UITour or set up a WebChannel so Monitor can open about:logins.

labels.name: effort-M
labels.description: Expected to take a week for engineering to complete.

issues.body: The recommendation `Update other logins using the same password` should be followed by a CTA that says `View logins in Firefox` and opens `about:logins` if the user's browser is Firefox. To open `about:logins` we need to add Monitor to the list of websites allowed to do this, and then set up a WebChannel or use UITour to open `about:logins` in a new tab.

issues.title: Change of primary email address (in FF Accounts) not applied to Monitor

labels.name: defect
labels.description: Issue describes a defect that negatively impacts use.

labels.name: effort-M
labels.description: Expected to take a week for engineering to complete.

issues.body:
I had two email addresses (gmail & mailbox), both in my FF account and in Monitor. I have changed my primary email address in my Firefox account (from gmail to mailbox).

After applying this change in my FF account, I refreshed the preferences page of Monitor to see if the primary address would update there too, but that didn't happen.

I logged out from Monitor, and logged in again (via FF account), with my mailbox account (as it's the primary one now). I entered Monitor, but my secondary (gmail) address is no longer listed. This makes me assume seems I am in a different, new Monitor account.

To verify this assumption, I changed again my FF primary email address, logged out of Monitor, and logged in again via FF (using my primary email address). Voila, there my gmail (intended secondary) shows up again.

Am I indeed correct with my assumption? Isn't this a security risk (an unused account remaining available on Monitor until eternity)? How can I delete my unused, gmail-as-primary account from Monitor?

issues.title: Switch to server-side session storage

labels.name: effort-M
labels.description: Expected to take a week for engineering to complete.

labels.name: task
labels.description: Issue describes a task that needs to be completed but is not a defect or enhancement in itself.

issues.body:
https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/issues/1146 and https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/issues/1084 show that we can't rely on client-sessions forever. As we put more data into user session objects, we need to move it to server-side session storage.

@mozilla/svcops - what are the suggested storage backends for (node) sessions?

issues.title: Audit our usage of sha1() and .toLowerCase() when scanning emails.

labels.name: defect
labels.description: Issue describes a defect that negatively impacts use.

labels.name: effort-S
labels.description: Expected to take less than a week for engineering to complete.

issues.body: We occasionally run into issues (most recently, #1461) stemming from our usage of `sha1()` and `.toLowerCase()` causing false negative scan results when the scanned email address contains uppercase letters. Let's audit/standardize/demystify/betterify the `sha1()`/`.toLowerCase()` steps in all the places we scan emails so that we don't unintentionally confuse someone or give them a false sense of security by providing incorrect scan results in the future.

issues.title: Link password manager names to their respective sites?

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Issue describes an improvement or addition to the product.

issues.body:
Ref: https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/pull/123#pullrequestreview-124151790

Currently we seem to be displaying password manager names in two places.

![firefox_monitor](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/557895/46041370-7217fe00-c0c7-11e8-957a-d478f0fde091.png)

**Figure 1:** /tips.js:27

https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/c7560a146198b3fdc4266be2ddcaa2de57da7745/tips.js#L27

![blurts-results](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/557895/46041531-d9ce4900-c0c7-11e8-8456-8ba54148b9b5.png)

**Figure 2:** /views/partials/what_to_do.hbs:14

https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/blob/cd378493ddad5f380187ca49bf35fa6c6986796d/views/partials/what_to_do.hbs#L14

We also recently had a request (ref: #459) to add Bitwarden to the list. I feel like it'd be a nice touch/courtesy to add `<a href="">` links to each of those sites. We could open them in new tabs using `target="_blank"` and do noopener and noreferrer and nofollow or whatever else we think makes sense. But we could also add some GA around the outbound links to try and see how many people are actively going out to those sites using the links.
Currently users have to copy/paste and type the product name into Gmail/Bing/AskJeeves and try and find the official site, which is kind of a drag.

issues.title: Switch to server-side session storage

labels.name: effort-M
labels.description: Expected to take a week for engineering to complete.

labels.name: task
labels.description: Issue describes a task that needs to be completed but is not a defect or enhancement in itself.

issues.body:
https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/issues/1146 and https://github.com/mozilla/blurts-server/issues/1084 show that we can't rely on client-sessions forever. As we put more data into user session objects, we need to move it to server-side session storage.

@mozilla/svcops - what are the suggested storage backends for (node) sessions?

issues.title: Resolved/Unresolved status of the breach is not changed after clicking the Back button of the browser
issues.body:
[Affected versions]:

Firefox 72.0.2 and Safari

[Affected Platforms]:

MacOS 10.14

[Steps to reproduce]:

1. Navigate to https://monitor-v2.herokuapp.com/
2. Log into a Firefox Monitor account that monitors multiple email addresses
3. Find a breach that is common for more than one email address (3 in my case) and click anywhere on its surface.
4. In the "Marking this breach as resolved" section, click on "Mark as Resolved" button only for one email account.
5. Click on the "Return to the breach detail" option
6. Click on "Back" button from the browser

[Expected result]:

The status of the breach should be changed into Resolved.

[Actual result]:

Page is not refreshed and status is not changed.

[Additional Info]:

The same thing happens  when you "Undo" the breach.
